book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship part 1
author: Krzysztof Martens
main_technique: Make a fool of the dangerous opponent
key_insight: The jack of hearts wins the trick in dummy. Lead the seven of diamonds to the ten – finesse the queen the other way round 'from the rear'
solution_line: 1. The jack of hearts wins the trick in dummy. 2. Lead the seven of diamonds to the ten – finesse the queen the other way round 'from the rear'. If the queen of diamonds was with North, such a move will not hurt. he will not be able to continue hearts effectively. After taking the trick with the ten of diamonds, play a diamond to the king.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 3NT (E), Lead ♠10 +600 for Israel. You made a fool of the opponent: +660 = +2 IMP. You did not find this line: −12 IMP.

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship part 1
author: Krzysztof Martens
key_insight: The main danger is that South will hold a club trick. in that case you will need to find the spade king onside. However, you will need an additional entry to dummy to finesse spades twice
solution_line: Order of play: 1. Win the trick with the ace in your hand. 2. Play the ace of clubs. 3. Play the queen of clubs and, when North does not follow suit, overtake with the king. 4. Finesse the spade queen. 5. Concede a club trick to the jack.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 3NT, down one, +50 for NS. You made the contract: +10 IMP. You went down: no swing.

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship part 1
author: Krzysztof Martens
main_technique: Look for the safest way to establish a side suit
key_insight: Win with the queen of trumps. Duck a round of clubs. After any lead back do the following: Cross to the dummy with the jack of hearts and ruff a club low. Draw trumps and reach your clubs with the king of spades
solution_line: Order of play: 1. Win with the queen of trumps. 2. Duck a round of clubs. 3. After any lead back do the following: 4-5. Cross to the dummy with the jack of hearts and ruff a club low. Draw trumps and reach your clubs with the king of spades.
result_comparison: Closed room – the Israeli pair stopped in 3 NT. Result +490 for EW. You played the slam well: +10 IMP. You failed: −11 IMP.

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship part 1
author: Krzysztof Martens
key_insight: You aim for an elopement play on the tenth trick. Ruff the diamond lead and cash your ace and king of spades. Cross the dummy with the ♥10. Ruff a diamond! Why – you will see in a minute
solution_line: Order of play: 1-3. Ruff the diamond lead and cash your ace and king of spades. 4. Cross the dummy with the ♥10. 5. Ruff a diamond! Why – you will see in a minute. 6-8. Play your hearts pitching clubs from the dummy. For obvious reasons, the opponents refuse to ruff the hearts, which break 3-3. 9-10. Ruff the last heart in the dummy and ruff a diamond. You have to find North with one of the following layouts: 3-3-5-2 or 3-4-4-2 to succeed with your plan. A key play was ruffing the second diamond.
result_comparison: Closed Room – Contract 2♠, +140 for EW. You saw the need to ruff the second diamond: +620 = +10 IMP. You failed to do it: −6 IMP.

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship part 1
author: Krzysztof Martens
main_technique: Let you opponents do the job for you
key_insight: Ruff with the ace of spades. Cross to dummy with the ♠9, the opponents following the suit. Ruff a club. Draw a second round of trumps with the king. Play the king and the ace of hearts. Discard a heart on the last club
solution_line: Order of play: 1. Ruff with the ace of spades. 2. Cross to dummy with the ♠9, the opponents following the suit. 3. Ruff a club. 4. Draw a second round of trumps with the king. 5-6. Play the king and the ace of hearts. 7. Discard a heart on the last club. Check that the opponents are helpless, regardless of the distribution of suits and honours.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 4♠, +420 for EW. You played accurately: +1 IMP. You did not find the right solution: −10 IMP.

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship part 1
author: Krzysztof Martens
main_technique: Find a tiny chance to win
key_insight: Win the ace of spades in your hand. Play a heart to the ace. When the queen falls, draw two rounds of trumps leaving an honour in the dummy. Play the jack of hearts. Additional chance is a single queen of hearts with two trumps with the same opponent
solution_line: Order of play: 1. Win the ace of spades in your hand. 2-4. Play a heart to the ace. When the queen falls, draw two rounds of trumps leaving an honour in the dummy. 5. Play the jack of hearts. Additional chance is a single queen of hearts with two trumps with the same opponent. 6-7. Cross to dummy with a club and ruff a heart. You can say that I was critical about looking for additional chances. True, but if you are familiar with a technique, careful play costs you nothing. If the opponents play small cards on the first round of hearts, the suit will have to break 3-2. In that case, trumps may even break 4-1.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 6♥ +980 for EW. (Lead ♣9. You played a heart to the ace and drew two rounds of trumps –2 IMP. You played it differently −14 IMP.

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship part 1
author: Krzysztof Martens
key_insight: Win in the dummy with ♥9. Play ♠8 to the ten. If the finesse works, ruff two spades, if not, you have two entries to dummy to lead towards your diamond honours
solution_line: Order of play: 1. Win in the dummy with ♥9. 2. Play ♠8 to the ten. If the finesse works, ruff two spades, if not, you have two entries to dummy to lead towards your diamond honours.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 4♥, +620 for EW. If you played that way: no swing. If you ran the queen of spades: −12 IMP.

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship part 1
author: Krzysztof Martens
main_technique: Assume that the layout that will let you make this optimistic contract
key_insight: The 2♥ opening was made with a poor suit, so you may assume that both kings are with South. Then you can make it if the king of clubs is doubleton
solution_line: The 2♥ opening was made with a poor suit, so you may assume that both kings are with South. Then you can make it if the king of clubs is doubleton. Order of play: 2. Cross to your hand with a trump. 3. Cash the ace of hearts pitching a diamond. 4. Cross the dummy with a spade. 5. Finesse the king of diamonds. 6-7. Play the ace of clubs and a club ducking in the dummy. 8. a) if South has a spade to play back then he holds the king of diamond doubleton. b) South plays for ruff and discard, ruff in your hand pitching a diamond from the dummy. Then play the ace of diamonds and ruff a diamond. Cross to your hand with a spade.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 4♠, +650 for EW. The contract was very difficult to make and required a lot of precision: +13 IMP. No wonder that you have failed: −13 IMP.

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship part 1
author: Krzysztof Martens
key_insight: Play the queen of hearts from your hand. The opponents have to hold up. Ruff a spade, get back with the king of diamonds to your hand. Cash the ace of hearts
solution_line: Order of play: 2. Play the queen of hearts from your hand. The opponents have to hold up. 3-4. Ruff a spade, get back with the king of diamonds to your hand. 5. Cash the ace of hearts. 6-7. Overtake the queen of diamonds with the ace and discard a spade on the third diamond.
result_comparison: The Israeli pair bid and made 6♦ after a club lead. Result: +920 for EW. You played the queen of hearts: +980 = +2 IMP. Otherwise: −14 IMP.

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship part 1
author: Krzysztof Martens
main_technique: Do not give up even in hopeless situations
key_insight: Ruff a heart. Cross with a club and ruff a heart. Cross with a club. Play hearts. Three trumps with South give some hope for a squeeze or Q-J-x of spades
solution_line: Order of play: 1. Ruff a heart. 2-3. Cross with a club and ruff a heart. 4. Cross with a club. 5 – Play hearts. Three trumps with South give some hope for a squeeze or Q-J-x of spades. As you can see, if you find the layout you need, South is helpless.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 3NT, +660 for EW. You executed this complicated play: +13 IMP. You failed: −13 IMP. You could really show your best in this match. A gain of 59 IMP = 25-4 VP win. You next opponents will be a team from Belgium.
